Correlation of degree of connector nodes

Source: R/coid.R
coid.Rd

Calculating correlation of degree of connector nodes.

coid(
  network.or.subnet_mat1,
  subnet_mat2 = NULL,
  weighted = FALSE,
  weight_type = "shannon",
  method = "kendall"
)

Arguments

network.or.subnet_mat1

An Igraph object or matrix. An "igraph" object with node attribute 'level' or a matrix representing one subnetwork. See details.

subnet_mat2

A matrix representing one subnetwork.

weighted

Logical. Default to FALSE. If TRUE, the degree of a connector node is replaced with Shannon diversity or sum of its interaction strengths.

weight_type

For weighted==TRUE only, the definition of weighted degree for a connector node, supporting "shannon" or "sum".

method

Correlation method ("pearson", "kendall" or "spearman"). Default to "kendall".

Value

Return a numeric value representing correlation of interaction degree for connector nodes: CoID.

Details

In this package, a tripartite network contains three groups of nodes (a-nodes,b-nodes,c-nodes) and two subnetworks (P includes the links between a-nodes and b-nodes, Q includes the links between b-nodes and c-nodes). Connector nodes belong to b-nodes.

This function follows Sauve et al.(2016)) to calculate the correlation of interaction degree (or Shannon diversity of interaction strength ) of connector nodes. For the binary network, connector nodes' degree is calculated in each subnetwork. For the quantitative network, Shannon diversity or sum of interaction strength for each connector node (i) is calculated. Three correlation methods are provided. Kendall correlation is recommended following Sauve et al.(2016).

Two types of inputs network.or.subnet_mat1 can be processed:

  • An "igraph" object with node attribute 'level' (0 for a-nodes, 1 for b-nodes,2 for c-nodes)

  • Or a matrix representing subnetwork P, and must be input with subnet_mat2 representing subnetwork Q.

If the inputs are two matrices, please make sure the rows of network.or.subnet_mat1 and subnet_mat2 both represent the groups of connector species,i.e, the b-group species. If both matrices have row names, then the function matches row names to produce connector nodes. Otherwise, row numbers are assigned to row names and matched. Within the two matrices (P and Q), columns represents a-group nodes and c-group nodes respectively. Elements in matrices are non-zero values if two nodes are linked with or without weights, and 0 otherwise.

References

Sauve, A. M., ThC)bault, E., Pocock, M. J., & Fontaine, C. (2016). How plants connect pollination and herbivory networks and their contribution to community stability. Ecology, 97(4), 908-917.

Examples


## generate a random binary tripartite network
set.seed(12)
Net <- build_net(11,15,16,0.2)
coid(Net)
#> CoID= -0.42609923;
#> [1] -0.4260992

## empirical network
data(PPH_Coltparkmeadow)
Net <- PPH_Coltparkmeadow
coid(Net)
#> CoID= 0.16798421;
#> [1] 0.1679842
set.seed(13)
E(Net)$weight<-runif(length(E(Net)),0.1,1)#random weights assigned
#> Error in E(Net): could not find function "E"
coid(Net,weighted=T)
#> CoID_weighted= 0.16798421;
#> [1] 0.1679842

##input as binary matrices, with row names.
set.seed(12)
md1 <- matrix(sample(c(0,1),8*11,replace=TRUE),8,11,dimnames = list(paste0("b",1:8),paste0("c",1:11)))
md2 <- matrix(sample(c(0,1),10*12,replace=TRUE),10,12,dimnames = list(paste0("b",1:10),paste0("a",1:12)))
coid(md1,md2)
#> CoID= -0.21821789;
#> [1] -0.2182179

##input as weighted matrices,with row numbers as row names.
set.seed(12)
mdw1 <- matrix(sample(c(rep(0,40),runif(48,0,1))),8,11)
mdw2 <- matrix(sample(c(rep(0,40),runif(80,0,1))),10,12)
coid(mdw1,mdw2)
#> No rownames for matrices, so row IDs are used!
#> CoID= 0.04264014;
#> [1] 0.04264014
coid(mdw1,mdw2,weighted=T)
#> No rownames for matrices, so row IDs are used!
#> CoID_weighted= 0.14285714;
#> [1] 0.1428571
coid(mdw1,mdw2,weighted=T, weight_type="sum")
#> No rownames for matrices, so row IDs are used!
#> CoID_weighted= -0.07142857;
#> [1] -0.07142857
